bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural operations include the production activities related to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: apiculture,
berry farming,
Christmas tree culture,
composting,
dairy farming,
egg farming,
forest seedling and seed production,
grain and oilseed production,
greenhouse operations,
herb production,
horticulture, including floriculture, tree nurseries and ornamental nurseries,
insects raised for biological pest control,
orchards,
poultry farming,
a riding academy, or the boarding or breeding of horses,
seed production,
sod or turf production,
vegetable farming,
wool, hide, feather or fur production, and
the raising of crops or animals for human or animal consumption,
the production of agricultural byproducts or of manufactured derivatives from agricultural raw material,
the breeding or raising of pets other than horses, or
aquaculture;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: agricultural tractor means a vehicle, with more than 20 engine horsepower, running on wheels, designed to furnish the power to pull, carry, propel or drive an implement that is designed or used for agriculture, but does not include a self-propelled implement;
farm land means land used for agricultural operations;
low-profile tractor means an agricultural tractor with the following characteristics:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the front wheel spacing is equal to the rear wheel spacing, as measured from the centre line of each right wheel to the centre line of the corresponding left wheel;
the clearance from the bottom of the tractor chassis to the ground does not exceed 46 cm (18 in);
the highest point of the hood does not exceed 1.5Â m (60 in);
the tractor is designed so that the operator straddles the transmission when seated;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: orchard ladder means a self-supporting portable ladder of the tripod type, wide at the bottom and tapering towards the top, non-adjustable in length, and consisting of side rails, flat steps and a hinged, single leg back section.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Part applies to agricultural operations on farm land.
Cold storage rooms must have at least one door that can, at all times, be opened from inside the room.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Bridges and culverts under roadways within the agricultural workplace must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: designed, constructed and maintained so as to safely support the heaviest load expected to be imposed on them, and
of sufficient width to permit equipment and machinery to cross safely.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A bridge within the agricultural workplace must also be provided with bullrails not less than 25 cm (10 in) in height.
Where manure or other material is loaded into pits by self-propelled equipment, the employer must install barriers sufficient to prevent the equipment from falling or inadvertently entering the pit.
If the use of barriers required by subsection (1) is not practicable, the employer must adopt procedures that provide equivalent protection for workers.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Instruction of seasonal, temporary and other workers
bcl:section.bcl:text: When workers, including seasonal and temporary workers, start employment, the employer and the employer's supervisor must ensure that they are instructed about the safe performance of their duties.

If an agricultural tractor is proposed to be used without a ROPS under section 16.34 (2) (b), in addition to the factors listed in section 16.34 (1) to be considered in the rollover risk assessment, the qualified person must also consider the training and experience of the operator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer must ensure that workers have a safe means of escape from any enclosure occupied by animals that are potentially dangerous to workers.
If a worker is required to handle animals, the employer must ensure that the worker is effectively instructed and trained and is competent to perform the assigned work.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 4.70 to 4.80 (Indoor air quality) do not apply to a private residence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Control of environmental tobacco smoke and e-cigarette vapour exception
bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 4.81 and 4.82 (Environmental tobacco smoke and e-cigarette vapour) do not apply in a private residence, except when a worker, other than the occupant of the residence, is working in the residence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer must ensure that an adequate supply of potable drinking water is available to workers during the workday.
Water in irrigation ditches or other similar sources is not potable drinking water for the purposes of subsection (1).
If drinking water is provided in portable dispensers, the dispensers must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: equipped with a tap,
capable of being covered, and
maintained in a sanitary condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Workers must be informed of any water supplies that are unsafe to drink.
Section 5.82 (2) (a) and (b) does not apply to agricultural operations on farm land.

If work processes involving substances such as lead, mercury, asbestos, silica or pesticides are high hazard, the employer must ensure that workers are provided with adequate and appropriate shower and change facilities.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 199/2014, App. J, s. 1.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 6.116 to 6.132 (Toxic process gases) do not apply to anhydrous ammonia fertilization systems.
If anhydrous ammonia is stored or used for the purpose of fertilization, the employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the equipment containing anhydrous ammonia is inspected before each use, to prevent accidental leakage or spillage,
the hose end-valves are in the closed position when the equipment is not operating, and
the relief and vapour valves are positioned so that any discharge is directed upwards and away from the worker's operating position.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ventilation of buildings near manure tanks

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A worker must not enter or remain in a building or structure adjoining a liquid manure tank while the manure is being agitated.
Following agitation of the manure, any adjoining building or structure must be thoroughly ventilated before a worker is permitted to re-enter it.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 8.23 (Non-slip footwear) does not apply to a work activity involving horseback riding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Warning signs for power take-off devices
bcl:section.bcl:text: At conspicuous locations near rotating shafts driven by power take-off devices, warning signs must be located specifying that shields must be kept in place.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Signs and procedures for equipment guarding
bcl:section.bcl:text: If the removal of a guard or access door would expose a worker to a component that continues to rotate after the power to the component has been disengaged,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the employer must apply a sign to the guard or access door warning of the danger, and
the guard must not be removed or access door opened until enough time has elapsed to bring all components to a complete stop.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A worker using a hay baler must not attempt to clear hay from the collection area unless the engine is stopped and cannot be inadvertently started.
A worker must keep clear of the discharge area of a round baler and the area under the hatch unless the hatch is blocked open.
A post-hole digger must have

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tractor or machine brakes set before digging,
shear bolts as specified by the manufacturer, and
a hold-to-run control when operated as a hand-held unit.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A worker operating a post driver must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: lower the hammer and stop the engine when adjustment or maintenance is required,
if necessary for safety, steady the post with a steady fork or guide, and
lower or block the hammer when the machine is not in use.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 12.72 does not apply to a chain saw used in agricultural operations on farm land, if the chain saw was purchased for first use before DecemberÂ 31,Â 1993.
A hand winch for raising an auger conveyor must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a control that will hold the auger at any angle, and
respond only when the handle is turned.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Alternative means of evaluation for automotive lifts and vehicle supports

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 12.76, if written instructions are not available from the manufacturer or a professional engineer, the instructions may be provided instead by any other person qualified to develop them.

Despite sections 4.8 and 12.79, if a modification is made to a device listed in section 12.79 (1) or if the manufacturer's rated capacity is not known, the rated capacity may be determined by a person qualified to do so.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 13.2 (1) and 13.5 (a), (b) and (c) do not apply to orchard ladders.
An orchard ladder must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: meet the construction requirements of CSA Standard CAN3-Z11-M81, Portable Ladders, except that the spreader requirement does not apply to orchard ladders,
have a rail spread that increases at least an average of 6 cm (2.5 in) for each 30 cm (12 in) of ladder length, and
when necessary for safety, have the feet of the ladder equipped with steel points or other non-slipping bases designed for the ground on which the ladder will be used.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the ladder used is appropriate for the task, and
a worker using an orchard ladder is instructed in its proper use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 422/2004, s. 4.]

bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 13.2 (1) (a), a fixed ladder existing on or before January 1, 2006, and not conforming to the current or an earlier edition of ANSI Standard A14.3-1992, Safety Requirements for Fixed Ladders, may remain in use subject to any modifications considered necessary by the Board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 14.2 to 14.33 and 14.44 do not apply to a job built crane or hoist for use on site with a rated capacity of less than 1 tonne (2Â 200Â lbs) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the device is built or otherwise assembled by a person qualified to do the work,
the rated capacity of the device, including support structures, is determined by a person qualified to make the assessment,
the rated capacity is marked on the device and is not exceeded,
the device is not used to support a worker,
the device is operated so that a worker is not under the load,

the device is inspected and maintained at a frequency and to the extent required to ensure that every component is capable of carrying out its original design function with an adequate margin of safety,
inspection and maintenance records are maintained for the device consistent with Part 4 (General Conditions), and
any modifications to the device are made by a person qualified to do the work.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the Board may require compliance with sections 14.2 to 14.33 and 14.44 if the design of the equipment or the circumstances of use indicate the need.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Altered application dates for cranes and hoists

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The certification of drop stops required under section 14.19 (2) must be completed by January 1, 2006.
Section 14.54 applies to a bridge, overhead or gantry crane, if installed after JanuaryÂ 1,Â 2006, or to a crane or its runway if it is modified after that date.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The requirements for identification of various rigging components in sections 15.5, 15.24 (3), 15.42, 15.46, 15.52, 15.55 and 15.59 may also be met if the employer is able to determine the information required for a particular device by any means of identification specific to it.
The requirements of sections 15.6 (2), 15.27, 15.28 (1), 15.32 and 15.36 for the competency of a person evaluating a device may be met by a person who is qualified to conduct the evaluation.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 139/2021, App. D, s. 15.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for mobile elevating work platforms
bcl:section.bcl:text: A mobile elevating work platform used in an orchard must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have a platform equipped with a non-skid surface,
be provided with a drive system that ensures there will be no unintended movement of the unit, and
not be operated on sloping ground unless

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: specific instructions from the manufacturer for the operation are followed, and
the unit is equipped with a braking system capable of restraining the machine under any condition of use, or the unit is equipped with wheels that will not turn unless driven.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Mobile elevating work platform design standards

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided by subsection (2), a mobile elevating work platform used in an orchard must meet the requirements of section 13.2 (1).
A mobile elevating work platform may be used in an orchard if it has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a platform equipped with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a gate that does not swing outward and that can be securely fastened in the closed position to minimize the risk of accidental opening,
a top rail approximately 90 cm (36 in) in height above the floor and capable of withstanding a load of 890Â NÂ (200Â lbs) applied in any direction at any point on the top rail, and
a toe rail, on the sides not serviced by a gate, which is approximately 8 cm (3 in) in height with a maximum clearance between the floor and the bottom edge of the toe rail of 5Â cm (2Â in), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for equipment manufactured after December 31, 1993, a maximum platform height of 3.6Â m (12Â ft).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Identification on mobile elevating work platforms
bcl:section.bcl:text: A mobile elevating work platform used in orchards, if manufactured after December 31, 1993, must have the following information permanently and conspicuously marked on it:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: certification to confirm the standard met by the device;
the make, model, serial number and manufacturer's name;
the rated platform workload;
the maximum platform height and travel height;
the maximum slope on which the device may be operated when the platform is elevated.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 13.33 (1) and Part 11 (Fall Protection) do not apply to a worker using a mobile elevating work platform in an orchard if the platform height is 3.6Â m (12Â ft) or less.

For the purposes of application of sections 13.12 and 13.23 (1) (b), a person may make the inspection and determination of safety for continued use of a mobile elevating work platform used in orchards if the person is qualified to do so, and the work platform has a maximum operational height of 3.6 m (12 ft).
Sections 13.24 (2), 13.25 and 13.26 do not apply to mobile elevating work platforms when they are used in orchards at a height of 3.6Â m (12Â ft) or less.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 139/2021, App. D, s. 15.]
Despite sections 16.8 and 16.20 and Part 17, a person other than the operator may be transported on mobile equipment that is not designed for the transportation of workers, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person is safely seated, and
the mobile equipment is operated at no more than 10 km/h (6 mph).
